title: 112_hr6561
content:
The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for preventing teacher layoffs and creating jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves funds for assistance to outlying areas, the Secretary of the Interior, and administration and oversight of the program. The Secretary allocates funds for activities in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Education, with a maximum of $2,000,000 reserved for administration and oversight. Award amounts for each State are determined based on population ratios of individuals aged 5 through 17. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on population ratios of individuals aged 5 through 17. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds to other States using a specific formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include assurances that the State will maintain support for education at or above the levels of fiscal year 2011 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. State chief executives must submit an application within 30 days of the Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include assurances to maintain support for education at or above fiscal year 2011 levels for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The Secretary may waive requirements for a State under certain circumstances. The Secretary may waive the requirement for a State to provide assurances under certain circumstances, such as natural disasters or financial decline. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve a portion for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education support. The grant funds received by each State must be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education support. The funds are distributed through subgrants based on the enrollment ratio of each local educational agency in the State. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. Subgrants should be made available to agencies within 100 days of receiving the grant. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios and make subgrants available within 100 days. Grant funds cannot be used to establish, restore, or supplement a rainy-day fund, supplant State funds, reduce debt obligations, or supplant funds to reduce debt obligations. SEC. 105. Local educational agency subgrants must be used for retaining, recalling, or hiring employees for educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106. Early learning programs. SEC. 106. Early learning programs funded by the state must use funds for retaining, recalling, or hiring early childhood educators. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107. Reporting requirements for states receiving grants under this title. SEC. 108. Definitions. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms like "local educational agency", "outlying area", and "State educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also clarifies that "State" refers to the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. Additionally, it explains that a "State-funded early learning program" is a program for children from birth to kindergarten entry that receives State funding. SEC. 109. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $30 billion is authorized for the grant program under this title for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. TITLE II--FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION

SEC. 201. PURPOSE.

    This title aims to provide funds to States and localities to prevent layoffs of, and support the creation of additional jobs for, law enforcement officers and firefighters. 

SEC. 202. FIREFIGHTER GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. An additional $1 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for this purpose. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants totaling $1 billion for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain fire department resources. Additionally, $2 million is reserved each fiscal year for administrative costs. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. An additional $4 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
